patterns.pattern: First-time contributors (0 prior PRs) with missing critical metadata (LoC, files changed, tests, CI status) face significant merge uncertainty despite category or change-type signals
Experienced-contributor or trusted-contributor labels provide +5-15% credibility boost and can compensate for weak author merge history
XS/S size labels correlate with 26-28% merge rates and provide strongest compensatory signal for weak author credentials
Authors with 100% prior merge rate history (even single PR) signal strong credibility and >50% merge likelihood when paired with focused scope
Authors with prior merge rate significantly above 24% baseline demonstrate predictive capability independent of PR scope and metadata
Fix-type changes in high-priority categories (agents, gateway) provide +15-25% baseline uplift
Low-merge authors (merge rate <5% across 5+ prior PRs) face deterministic rejection risk that size labels and category signals cannot overcome
Multi-channel or multi-component changes from first-time/weak-history authors create elevated risk requiring compensatory signals (maintainer labels, explicit approvals)
Critical-path infrastructure changes from new or underperforming authors require explicit credibility signals (maintainer label, prior merge history) to offset systemic risk
Documentation-only PRs from first-time contributors have depressed baseline (~20-25%) that XS size labels can partially offset to 26-28% range
Authors with 15-25% prior merge rate near baseline benefit from narrow scope and fix-type classification for moderate merge likelihood
Missing metadata (LoC, test coverage, CI status) imposes ~7-8% confidence penalty but is mitigated by established author track record or explicit labels
Trusted-contributor labels paired with above-baseline merge history enable strong merge signal even on multi-component or multi-channel changes
Narrow, focused scope (single component/category) provides +5-10% boost for first-time contributors but insufficient alone without compensatory signals
Authors with 40%+ prior merge rate or experienced-contributor labels are strong merge candidates independent of size and scope signals
